{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3387696,"name":"Chris Bonomi","username":"BonomiC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bonomic/{size}/228966_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T16:39:06.994Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone,

Team 195 - CyberKnights is proud to present our 2024 robot code! Including a guide to getting started with ROS2 for FRC.

GitLab

CyberKnights / ROS2 / Robots / Knight_Shift / knight_shift_robot · GitLab

GitLab Enterprise Edition

Here you will find our main robot project. The README should contain everything you need to get up and running with running our ROS2 project locally in a simulator. Both Windows and Linux are currently supported.

IMG_54471920×1040 224 KB

If you have any questions about anything, please feel free to ask to help others and to help us improve our instructions!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-05-17T16:39:06.994Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":229,"reads":697,"readers_count":696,"score":1839.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466430,"topic_slug":"team-195-2024-ros2-quick-start-code-release","display_username":"Chris Bonomi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://gitlab.team195.com/cyberknights/ros2/robots/knight_shift/knight_shift_robot","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"CyberKnights / ROS2 / Robots / Knight_Shift / knight_shift_robot · GitLab","clicks":189},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/1/d1796c94a2c170b40772e9ef373b4e5d92a84e52.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/develop-can-w-o-rio-use-laptop-as-master-w-sparkmax-neo-brushless/475738/2","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Develop CAN w/o Rio - use Laptop as Master w/ SparkMax /Neo Brushless","clicks":1},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/apriltag-detection-and-ros2-robot-for-reefscape-frc-season/480872/6","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Apriltag detection and ROS2 Robot for Reefscape FRC season","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":35}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66288,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"195 Software Mentor | Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/team-195-2024-ros2-quick-start-code-release/466430/1","custom_user_title":"195 Software Mentor | Drive Coach","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":35}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":35,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3396095,"name":"Joe Witcpalek","username":"wits","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wits/{size}/110752_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-06T19:03:38.032Z","cooked":"

@BonomiC

Question that I’ve been trying to rationalize. One of the benefits of ROS seems to be not having one thing crash the entire code.

One thing that has been concerning me a bit is in the current/traditional set up, if you lose a co-processor, you are likely only losing vision or some small – maybe important – part of your robot, but at worse, you still can drive and play defense. With the ROS setup, it seems like if you lose the co-processor, the whole robot is down because the orchestrator for the messages connecting all of the nodes is down.

It also seems like from the diagram you shared at champs, that if the CANiVore hooked to the co-processor failed, it would have the same effect as losing the co-processor itself because that is the one actually controlling the motor controller’s output (the one from the RoboRio is only doing enable/disable functions).

Are these assumptions/understandings correct? If so, are there things you do to create redundancies/fallback solutions, so if you were to lose a co-processor (or the CANiVore from the co-processor) your robot would have some set of minimal capability?

Thanks for your insight.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-06-06T19:03:38.032Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":569,"readers_count":568,"score":153.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":466430,"topic_slug":"team-195-2024-ros2-quick-start-code-release","display_username":"Joe Witcpalek","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29802,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/team-195-2024-ros2-quick-start-code-release/466430/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3396202,"name":"Chris Bonomi","username":"BonomiC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bonomic/{size}/228966_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-07T03:26:43.916Z","cooked":"

These are issues that we debated on for most of this past season, as we had many struggles with reliability, specifically with our Nvidia Jetson co-processor. We believe this to be the fault of the connector bridging the module itself to the IO carrier board, as it is not rated anywhere close to the shock a robot can experience throughout a match. We have seemingly solved this issue by switching to an Orange Pi 5, which requires no such connector, and can handle the shock much better (We ran this new setup along with a fully rewired robot at CT Champs and had 0 failures of the control system, minus 2 broken motors causing CAN problems ).

Regarding the CANiVore, we don’t particularly see it as a bigger point of failure, as a RIO only control system would still need a CANiVore to take advantage of the 10Mbit/s CANFD. So losing the RIO CANiVore would also lose control of all motors on its network.

We do still have plans to implement some kind of failover drivetrain control like we had in 2023, which as you said, would let us at least have the ability to play defense.

I think with the new Pi setup we have reached a place that we are very happy with, but we are still continuing to explore more robust options. And dreaming of a more powerful standard control system from 2026 onwards!

Out of curiosity, how are yall interacting (if you are at all) with NT from your ROS2 client? Weve been doing some work with CUDA accelerated AprilTag detection through ISSAC ROS but hit a wall when we tired to interact with NT4.

Currently our code does not make use of network tables, but it did at one point in the season to send the robots heading to our LimeLight 3G for MegaTag 2.

We were able to do this by compiling the allwpilib source into our docker container.

GitLab

docker/ck-ros2-lib/Dockerfile · master · CyberKnights / ROS2 / Support Files...

GitLab Enterprise Edition

This lets us interact with NT4 as one normally would.

how does yalls ros2 code interact with rev motor controllers? assuming that there are sparks on your robot ofc.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-10-12T04:38:08.436Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":210,"readers_count":209,"score":72.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":466430,"topic_slug":"team-195-2024-ros2-quick-start-code-release","display_username":"neev dadhania","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57670,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"204 programmer + electrical"},"post_url":"/t/team-195-2024-ros2-quick-start-code-release/466430/8","custom_user_title":"204 programmer + electrical","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3434337,"name":"Chris Bonomi","username":"BonomiC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bonomic/{size}/228966_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-13T23:55:54.307Z","cooked":"

The short answer is that it does not interact with REV products. Our 2 main reasons for this are:

  1. We are able to directly control CTRE devices over the CAN bus by connecting the co-processor to the network with a canivore.
  2. We have generally been pretty unimpressed with the motion control solutions offered by the Spark Max.

That being said, we have talked about attempting to create a way of controlling them over the wire like we did with our ROS1 code base (Sending command packets to the RIO to be applied to the motors). The driving reason for this being the ability to use Neo 550s which may package better than Falcons/Krakens in some mechanisms.

those are totally valid reasons! im currently working on native (no rio needed) rev CAN compatibility with a ros2 package and socketcan. if and when it works, ill link it over to ya if youd like.

I’ve heard that ROS is a professional approach to controlling autonomous mobile robots. But in FRC, it’s more like “driver presses a button and the robot moves its arm.” So, what is the advantage of using ROS over the command base in FRC?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-10-14T08:12:17.326Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":42.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466430,"topic_slug":"team-195-2024-ros2-quick-start-code-release","display_username":"sam liu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60033,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CE Student @ UWaterloo | 5516 Alum "},"post_url":"/t/team-195-2024-ros2-quick-start-code-release/466430/11","custom_user_title":"CE Student @ UWaterloo | 5516 Alum ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3434524,"name":"neev dadhania","username":"nevadexehs","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ecc23a/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-10-14T11:43:49.578Z","cooked":"

ngl imo, i see it as a cool pet project that i can do to gain skill with something that i used much more widely than wpilib. im a one man team and however far i get in the next two years will satisfy me.

however, i think the main benefits from ros in frc are modularity, simulation, and telemetry. 900’s impressive physics simulation work with gazebo recently is absolutely awesome and i dont think it could be replicated without much more work than necessary if one wasnt using ros. and 195’s fully native simulation capabilities are not any lesser.

in addition, using ros allows you to take advantage of ros specific robotics libraries to build some crazy autonomous routines or precision picknplace mechanisms
